text_description: The first film projector is brought to the country.

media_caption: Oscar Keesee and Edita Vital in Noli Me Tangere, 1961
article_title: Film 1896 Jose Rizal's life and works
text_description: Jose Rizal’s life and works will inspire many films, including Sisa, Noli Me Tangere, and El Filibusterismo of Gerardo de Leon. (Cesar Hernando Collection)
Espetaculo Cientifico de Pertierra is shown at Escolta. It is a show of chronophotographs.
Lumiere films and the cinematograph are introduced to the country courtesy of two Swiss, Leibman and Peritz.
Antonio Ramos, a Spanish officer, is the first to shoot and exhibit films in the country.
Jose Jimenez builds the first Filipino-owned theater, Cinematógrafo Rizal in Tondo.

media_credit: Photo from Eduardo de Leon Collection
text_description: Herbert Wyndham shoots a series of scenes at the Manila Fire Department, the first edited film in the Philippines. (Photo from Eduardo de Leon Collection)
Albert Yearsley shoots Rizal Day celebrations at Luneta Park; the film is released the following year.

Rizalina Photoplay Company is founded and produces La Vida de Jose Rizal, based on Edward Gross’s 1905 stage play. Albert Yearsley’s El Fusilamiento de Dr Jose Rizal is shown to the public one day ahead of La Vida de Jose Rizal.
Sirena Moving Company is formed by theater owner Luis Camas.
Edward Gross’s Noli Me Tangere is shown.
Edward Gross’s El Filibusterismo is released.
Jose Nepomuceno establishes the first Filipino-owned company, Malayan Movies.
Elena Jurado appears in two Hollywood films, White Hands and Four Flushers.

media_credit: Photo from James de la Rosa
text_description: Miracles of Love, directed by Vicente Salumbides, is shown. The film showcases the use of close-ups and fast-cutting, a first in Philippine cinema. (Photo from James de la Rosa)
The first censors body is established by the Philippine Assembly.
The first Filipino movie with sound, Ang Aswang, directed by George Musser, is shown.
The first sound stage is inaugurated, courtesy of Americans Eddie Tait and George Harris for Filippine Films.
Parlatone Hispano-Filipino is established.

media_caption: Richard Abeleardo's set for Ibong Adarna, 1941, at the sound stage of LVN Pictures lot in Quezon City
text_description: LVN’s Ibong Adarna, directed by Vicente Salumbides, the first Filipino film with color sequences painted frame by frame, is shown. (Photo from Mike de Leon)
Bureau of Information and Public Security under the Commission of the Interior handles film censorship in the country.
The importation of film stock is stopped; filmmaking grinds to a halt.

media_caption: Jose Cris Soto, Katy de la Cruz, and Pugo performing in bodabil, ca 1950
media_credit: Photo from National Library of the Philippines
text_description: Film directors direct film actors in stage shows which replace the movies in terms of popularity during this period. Stage shows are bodabil shows with a play at the end. (Photo from National Library of the Philippines)
The Board of Review for Moving Pictures is formed by Pres Manuel A. Roxas.
Manuel Conde produces his first Juan Tamad film Si Juan Tamad. It will be the first of a whole series which raises social and political issues. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

Manila Times Publishing Company establishes the Maria Clara Awards, the first award-giving film body in the Philippines. The first batch of winners are: Kamay ni Satanas (Best Picture); Gerardo de Leon (Best Director) and Reynaldo Dante (Best Actor), Kamay ni Satanas; and Nena Cardenas (Best Actress), Doble Cara. Photo: Maria Clara Awards trophy
Darna, the first film adaptation of the komiks story and directed by Fernando Poe Sr, is shown. It stars Rosa del Rosario as the titular superheroine.
Genghis Khan by Manuel Conde competes at the Venice Film Festival, the first Filipino film to compete in an international festival. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)
Republic Act 3060 creating the Board of Censors for Motion Pictures is passed.
The studio system begins to collapse. Lebran ends production of films, followed by Premiere and LVN.

media_caption: Pancho Magalona as Simoun in El Filibusterismo, 1962
text_description: El Filibusterismo by Gerardo de Leon is shown. It wins major FAMAS awards. Photo: Pancho Magalona as Simoun in El Filibusterismo, 1962 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

media_caption: Jet del Mundo and Robert Arevalo in Ang Daigdig ng mga Api, 1965
text_description: Both A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino and Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (in photo) participate in the first Manila Film Festival. The festival is the idea of Manila Mayor Antonio Villegas to celebrate the city’s foundation with the showing of quality films. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)
Board of Censors for Motion Pictures requires the submission of film scripts for approval.
The Movie Workers Welfare Foundation, Inc. (MOWELFUND) is established by then San Juan mayor Joseph Estrada.
The Metro Manila Film Festival is established, replacing the Manila Film Festival.

media_caption: Christopher de Leon and Nora Aunor in Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos, 1976
text_description: During this “golden year,” the following films are released: Ganito Kami Noon, Paano Kayo Ngayon? by Eddie Romero, Insiang by Lino Brocka, Itim by Mike de Leon, Nunal sa Tubig by Ishmael Bernal, Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (in photo) by Mario O’Hara, and Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo by Lupita A. Concio. (Photo from Mario Hernando)
The University of the Philippines Film Center (UPFC) is established, providing training ground for aspiring filmmakers.

The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino is formed. Its first batch of Gawad Urian winners includes: Ganito Kami Noon, Paano Kayo Ngayon, Best Picture; Vic Silayan, Best Actor for Ligaw na Bulaklak; Nora Aunor, Best Actress for Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos; and Eddie Romero, Best Director for Ganito Kami Noon, Paano Kayo Ngayon.
Mike de Leon wins Best Director and Charo Santos (in photo) wins Best Actress in the Asian Film Festival in Australia for Itim. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Fernando Poe Jr in Ang Panday, 1980
text_description: Ang Panday, directed by and starring Fernando Poe Jr and based on the Carlo Caparas komiks serial, is shown. This will later on spawn many sequels and remakes, both in film and television. (Photo from FPJ Productions)
The Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) is established primarily to financially assist in the making of quality films.

Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) is formed to oversee the activities of the major guilds, associations, and institutions in the Philippine film industry and upgrade Filipino films through workshops and awards.

Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino (KDPP) is founded under the FAP. A group of younger directors will later split from the KDPP to form the Directors Guild of the Philippines, Inc (DGPI) under Lino Brocka.

media_caption: Jay Ilagan, Charo Santos, Aida Carmona, Vic Silayan, Charito Solis, and Ruben Rustia in Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata, 1981
text_description: Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata, a film that alludes to authoritarianism, is shown. (Photo by Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Nora Aunor in Ishmael Bernal’s Himala, 1982
text_description: Himala wins the awards for Best Picture, Director (Ishmael Bernal), Story (Ricardo Lee), Cinematography (Sergio Lobo), Production Design (Raquel Villavicencio), Editing (Ike Jarlego Jr), Actress (Nora Aunor), Supporting Actress (Gigi Dueñas), and Supporting Actor (Spanky Manikan) at the Metro Manila Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)
Gerardo de Leon is posthumously declared National Artist for Film.
Himala directed by Ishmael Bernal wins the Bronze Hugo award at the Chicago International Film Festival. It is also shown at the Berlin International Film Festival.

To fight censorship, Lino Brocka and other film and theater artists establish the Free the Artist Movement, which later becomes the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP). Photo: CAP members, from left, Bienvenido Lumbera, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Behn Cervantes, Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and RC Constantino. (Lino Brocka Collection)

media_caption: Tony Santos and Vilma Santos in Sister Stella L., 1984
text_description: Mike de Leon’s Sister Stella L., with screenplay by de Leon, Jose Lacaba, and Jose Almojuela, is shown locally. It also competes in the 41st Venice Film Festival under the title Sangandaan. (Photo by Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Armida Siguion-Reyna, Cirio H. Santiago, and Atty Espiridion Laxa in a producers’ meeting, ca 1980
text_description: The Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) is replaced by the Film Development Foundation of the Philippines (FDFP). (Photo from Mario Hernando)
The first Shake, Rattle and Roll movie is shown. The three-episode film stars Joel Torre, Janice de Belen, Charito Solis, and Herbert Bautista, among others.

media_caption: Venchito Galvez, second from left, and Ariosto Reyes in Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim, 1984
text_description: Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim directed by Lino Brocka is shown. The film is initially denied an exhibition permit on grounds of subversion and inciting to rebellion. Brocka files a suit in the Supreme Court which results in the SC ordering the board to classify, not cut films. (Photo from Mario Hernando)
Boatman by Tikoy Aguiluz wins the Outstanding Film of the Year at the London Film Festival.

media_caption: Lino Brocka as Ramon Magsaysay Awardee, 1985
media_credit: Photo from Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation
text_description: Lino Brocka receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Journalism, Literature, and Creative Communication Arts. (Photo from Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation)
The Film Development Foundation of the Philippines is abolished.
Film producer and director Cirio Santiago is appointed by Pres Corazon Aquino as Officer-in-Charge of the Task Force on All Film-Related Government Agencies.

The new CCP management appointed by Pres Corazon Aquino reorients the institution and its programs to the thrusts of Filipinization, democratization, and decentralization. The CCP as the new national coordinating center for the arts now includes film and broadcast in its programs.
The Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video (Gawad Alternatibo) is established to honor young and promising filmmakers.
Revolutions Happen Like Refrains in a Song by Nick Deocampo wins the Grand Prize in the 9th International Super-8 and Video Festival in Brussels, Belgium.
Gawad CCP para sa Sining is established, with Lino Brocka as the first awardee for film.
Ishmael Bernal receives the Gawad CCP para Sa Sining for Film.
The Young Critics Circle-Film Desk is established, with its first awarding a year later.
Eddie S. Romero receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Lino Brocka dies in a car accident.
Brocka posthumously receives the Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Award.
The Manila Film Festival scandal happens. Ruffa Gutierrez and Gabby Concepcion are falsely announced as Best Actress and Best Actor winners instead of Aiko Melendez and Edu Manzano.
The MTRCB under Henrietta Mendez disapproves the nudity scenes in Schindler’s List by Steven Spielberg. Pres Fidel V. Ramos intervenes and the film is eventually screened with an R-16 rating.
Anita Linda receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for Film. Photo: Anita Linda in Adela, 2008 (Photo from Adolf Alix Jr)
Pres Fidel V. Ramos creates the MTRCB Appeals Committee.
Lino Brocka is posthumously given the National Artist Award for Film.
The Cinemanila International Film Festival is founded by director Tikoy Aguiluz.

media_caption: Ronnie Lazaro and John Arcilla in Raymond Red’s Anino, 2000
text_description: Anino by Raymond Red wins the Palme d’Or for short film at the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo from Raymond Red)
Ishmael Bernal posthumously receives the National Artist Award for Film.

media_caption: Yul Servo and Art Acuña in Lav Diaz’s Batang West Side, 2001
text_description: Batang West Side by Lav Diaz wins the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema award in the Cinemanila International Film Festival, and later on wins the Silver Screen Award for Best Asian Feature in the 2002 Singapore International Film Festival. (Photo by Cesar Hernando)
Dolphy and sons Eric and Jeffrey Quizon win as Best Actors for their roles in Gil Portes’s Markova: Comfort Gay in the Brussels International Film Festival Prix de la Meilleure Interpretation.
Eddie S. Romero becomes National Artist for Film.
Tikoy Aguiluz is awarded the Chevalier dans l’Ordre des Arts et Lettres prize by the French government for his contributions to Philippine cinema.
The 1937 film Zamboanga is recovered in the US National Archives and is sent to the Philippines.
Peque Gallaga receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for Film.

The Pink International Film Festival (PIFF), an international gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender themed film and video festival, is established in the Philippines to promote gay-themed films and to advocate for HIV/AIDS awareness.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is established. First batch of winners includes Pepot Artista for Best Film; Rica Arevalo, Best Director for ICU Bed#7; Meryll Soriano, Best Actress for Room Boy; Eddie Garcia, Best Actor for ICU Bed#7; and Special Jury Prize for Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros.
The Cinema One Originals Film Festival is established.
Fernando Poe Jr is posthumously recognized as National Artist for Film by Pres Gloria Arroyo, but his family refused to receive the award.
Himala is awarded the CNN APSA Viewers Choice Award for Best Asia-Pacific Film of all Time.
Manuel Conde is posthumously awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining (Film and Broadcast Arts).
100, written and directed by Chris Martinez, wins the KNN Audience Award in the 13th Busan International Film Festival.
Manuel Conde is posthumously bestowed the National Artist award for Film. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

article_title: Film 2012 Ang Babae Asian Film Awards
text_description: Ang Babae sa Septic Tank wins the People’s Choice Award for Favorite Actress (Eugene Domingo) in the Asian Film Awards.
Eugene Domingo wins the Best Actress award for her role in Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber's Tales) from the Tokyo International Film Festival.
Nora Aunor wins the Best Actress award from the 7th Asian Film Awards for her role in Thy Womb.
Jun Robles Lana wins Best Director of a Foreign Language Feature Film award for Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber's Tales) at the Madrid International Film Festival.
